subject: Issues after installing VAM Pro Linear Motors
description_text:
Hello,

This is all in reference to Order # SSN2057.

Pedals are great and have been using them without any issues. I just
received the haptic motors yesterday and have them installed and powered
on. I have the Brake Pedal haptic powered on using the ABS feedback mode
and testing works great.

Whenever I apply the brake to the point that the motors kick on, as soon as
I take my foot entirely off the brake pedal there is still input being
registered for maybe 3 seconds or so.. I've tried routing the brake haptic
away from the brake pedal but it still persists..

I have the control box mounted below my pedals and am curious if that is
causing the issue but I wouldn't think it would. I also cannot get my
throttle haptic to work when selecting TC under the Feedback Mode. It works
when I click and hold on the Vibration button but within iRacing if I spin
my tires it does not do anything. It's a bit frustrating and I haven't
turned them on yet since receiving and installing them.

-Shane C.

conversations.body_text: Hi Shane Clore,  I suspect there may be an issue with your installation: the brake pressure sensor must not come into contact with any brackets or the control box, as vibration can cause abnormal signal changes. Also, the test function is only for checking motor vibration and is not directly related to whether ABS or TC telemetry is enabled. I will provide you with a supported telemetry list, and you may also try using SIMHUB 9.9.3, which supports a wider range of telemetry types. Please note that SIMSONN Manager 2.1.0 and SIMHUB 9.9.3 cannot run at the same time. Could you provide photos of the front, back, and side of your pedals, as well as the installation of the VAM Pro? I will help you analyze the issue. Also, what is the brand of your wheelbase?

Here are pictures of the setup.

Pedals work fine it's just once the haptics are turned on the issue with
the brake happens.. I tried running the cable over the clutch thinking it
would potentially interfere with the brake but it still persists..

I'm running Simsonn Manager 2.1.0. I have a Fanatec DD Pro with a Club
Sport Steering wheel.

I cannot get the throttle haptic to provide any feedback when having TC
selected assuming it would vibrate when there is wheel slip on throttle.
Maybe I'm not setting it up correctly? I just want to be able to feel when
the tires are locking up on my brake pedal and when tires start slipping
when giving too much throttle. I am racing on iRacing Nascar cars.
[image: Screenshot 2025-08-12 213028.png][image: Screenshot 2025-08-12
213012.png]

On Sat, Aug 9, 2025 at 11:08 AM service@simsonn.com

Hi Shane Clore,    I’ve reviewed the photos you provided — the green grounding between the pedals and control box looks fine. However, the Fanatec base is known to cause electromagnetic interference (EMI), which can affect both the vibration motor and the control box. We recommend following the steps below to resolve the EMI issue — other customers with similar setups have resolved it this way as well.     To address EMI (Electromagnetic Interference) issues, please follow the steps below to improve device stability and USB connection reliability:     1.    Ensure proper grounding: Make sure the computer is connected to a three-prong outlet with a reliable ground. Two-prong plugs do not provide grounding.     2.    Control box grounding: Use a green shielding wire to connect the metal housing (such as a copper post or screw) of the control box to any metal screw on the pedal. Ensure the contact point is paint-free and conductive.     3.    Base grounding (e.g., Fanatec / MOZA): It’s recommended to connect the metal part of the base to the PC chassis or an external ground to discharge static buildup.     4.    Avoid high-interference zones: Keep USB cables away from high-voltage power lines or adapters; route cables separately where possible.     5.    Use direct USB connection: Connect devices directly to a rear USB 3.0 port on the PC instead of using unpowered or low-quality USB hubs.     6.    Use USB cables with ferrite cores: If needed, switch to high-quality USB cables with ferrite beads to reduce high-frequency interference.     7.    Keep software and firmware updated: Ensure SIMSONN Manager and firmware are updated to the latest version, as some updates include EMI handling improvements.     8.    Use a USB isolator: If the above methods don’t resolve the issue, using a USB isolator is recommended. It physically separates the USB power and data lines, effectively shielding the control device from EMI sources.     https://github.com/SHWotever/SimHub/wiki/USB-Issues-Troubleshooting https://support.gomezsimindustries.com/portal/en/kb/articles/understanding-emi-and-grounding   ​

Ok thanks I will try to work on that tomorrow. How will that answer the
issue with the Throttle haptic not responding to in game input? Do I have
the correct settings selected for what I am wanting?

*- I cannot get the throttle haptic to provide any feedback when having TC
selected assuming it would vibrate when there is wheel slip on throttle.
Maybe I'm not setting it up correctly? I just want to be able to feel when
the tires are locking up on my brake pedal and when tires start slipping
when giving too much throttle. I am racing on iRacing Nascar cars. *

On Tue, Aug 12, 2025 at 11:18 PM service@simsonn.com

Hi Shane Clore,  Has the TC telemetry been tested in SimHub 9.9.3 to confirm whether it can be triggered normally? Also, please let us know which game’s TC telemetry you are referring to so we can check. Please note that SimHub and SIMSONN Manager cannot be opened at the same time, as doing so will cause conflicts when reading telemetry data.

As previously mentioned I am on iRacing. I am using SimHub and the brake
pedal still persists. I've added power to the USB hub. I removed my wheel
from power and my computer to prevent any sort of EMI and the brake pedal
still has input when there is no pressure being applied. This is only as
soon as the haptics are turned on. When the haptics are turned off there is
no false input on the brake pedal.. This is incredibly frustrating.

On Wed, Aug 13, 2025 at 12:07 AM service@simsonn.com

Hi Shane Clore,  If testing is done with the Fanatec unpowered, there should be no EMI interference. The issue may be that the brake sensor is touching wires, the control box, or the bracket, transmitting vibrations to the brake pressure sensor. Please take photos of the brake installation from different angles and send them to me for confirmation. Additionally, please check whether the green wire from the PlusX control board is connected to any metal screws on the brake, as paint may affect the connection.

Sent from my iPhone 
Attachment(s) that exceed the 20 MB limit have been dropped. Please reach out to the sender.

Here is a video link of how it's responding within iRacing. At this point
I'm tempted to just return the pedals and haptics since I have yet to be
able to use them. I have yet to use the haptics that I spent $150 on.. I am
starting to wish I just went with the Fanatec v3 pedals..


Attachment(s) that exceed the 20 MB limit have been dropped. Please reach out to the sender.

https://youtu.be/eCOjGYgXrYQ


Attachment(s) that exceed the 20 MB limit have been dropped. Please reach out to the sender.

你好，Shane Clore，     From the images, the pedals work properly when the motors are not installed, which indicates that the pedals themselves are fine. The issue arises after the motors are installed. I believe the first step is to apply slightly more preload on the black locking nut of the brake damping to prevent poor return, ensuring that the signal can reset in time.  Additionally, please reset the offset and recalibrate, setting a 5% dead zone. Rest assured, choosing Simsonn pedals is definitely much better than Fanatec spring pedals. This pedal offers many adjustment options, so careful attention is needed.  Furthermore, you can use SimHub 9.9.3 to handle telemetry. If the signal response is slow, disabling filtering can provide faster feedback.

This is incredibly frustrating.. The pedals work FINE. As soon as I go into
Simsonn Manager 2.1.0 and within the Feedback Setting selecting ABS under
the haptic plugged into my brake pedal it keeps showing input when there is
no input. The input within the basic setting is also very jumpy and choppy
and not smooth as it should be based on my foot pushing the pedal.. I
increased the deadzone and the haptic will now not stick like before. Why
is this happening??

Is there a breakdown for how each feedback mode should work (i.e. Speed,
ABS, TC, Clutch, GearShift, etc)? My assumption is for ABS it should start
to vibrate as soon as my tires lock within iRacing correct?

I'm to the point where I just want to return these pedals because I've yet
to be able to use the haptics as I intended to when I made this purchase.
Yes they may have more features than the Fanatec v3 pedals but I wouldn't
be working with support on getting these haptics to work like one would
think they should..

On Sun, Aug 17, 2025 at 12:33 AM service@simsonn.com

Hi Shane Clore,  You can first use the Offset function to set the pedal deadzone to 0%, and then adjust it to 5%. This is normal. The pressure sensor will always show some data fluctuations. After offsetting and setting the deadzone, the pedal remains very sensitive. This is not an issue with the pedal.

I know the pedals are not the issue. I have said numerous times now the
pedals work just fine since I received them. The haptics are the problem.
Whenever a haptic is triggered it engages my brakes. *WHY IS THIS HAPPENING
HAS BEEN MY QUESTION SINCE AUG 6, 2025!u*

I have isolated the haptic cable running from the motors to the box so that
it touches nothing thinking maybe there is interference between wires
touching and that does nothing.

I have calibrated, set the offset and then set the deadzone for my brakes
to be 5-95. What settings am I missing to be able to effectively use these
haptics that I purchased?!

On Sun, Aug 17, 2025 at 10:27 PM service@simsonn.com

Hi Shane Clore,  Please turn off the Fanatec power and check whether the pedal’s test vibration and pedal operation are functioning properly.    Then, please provide a video of the pedal being tested. I want to check whether the pedal operates smoothly and the motor test works properly after the base power is turned off.      Please make sure the firmware is updated to the latest version. Then, go to “Settings → Update” and click “Manual Firmware Update”. Navigate to the pedals-firmware folder → pedals folder → and select the plusx.sfu file to perform the update. After updating, run the test. If everything works normally, it indicates that the issue is caused by EMI interference from the Fanatec base, as other customers have not encountered such complex problems.

I don't believe the issue is with the Fanatec base. I say this because when
I bought these pedals and haptics I was using a Logitech G293 wheel and it
was still happening. I have done all trouble shooting to isolate the issue
to be the brake pedal. Any sort of haptic input is triggering my brake
pedal to go off. As mentioned before, the pedals work with NO issue when
the haptics are turned off.

It is frustrating to see a reddit post with people claiming to have the
same problem with one person saying that they too are being told it's an
EMI issue.

How do I start the return process for the haptics and pedals?

On Tue, Aug 19, 2025 at 5:50 AM service@simsonn.com
Hi Shane Clore,    Please install ToDesk (no registration required) and provide me with the ID and temporary verification code. I am an engineer and can assist you remotely to resolve the issue.

Hi Shane Clore,  From our after‑sales analysis, most interference issues can be resolved by following our EMI checklist. For your case, I’ll assist you remotely to determine whether the root cause is hardware or software. If it’s confirmed that the VAM Pro or the main controller hardware is faulty, we will offer appropriate compensation.

I do not feel comfortable downloading a Chinese remote desktop software and
having you remote into my computer if I'm being honest.. What steps are you
looking to perform and I can do that and share the results.

On Tue, Aug 19, 2025 at 10:31 PM service@simsonn.com

Hi Shane Clore,     Your baseplate wiring looks very neat and tidy. I suggest removing the USB hub marked in the red circle and testing again to see if the EMI issue still exists. Since we have already exchanged more than 15 messages on this matter, I really want to help you resolve it quickly. Installing ToDesk is completely safe — it’s a remote desktop tool, and I will only operate under your full supervision. It usually takes me just a few minutes to identify the issue and provide an effective solution. Once the problem is solved, you can simply uninstall ToDesk right away.

Hi Shane Clore,  https://dl.todesk.com/windows/ToDesk_Setup.exe     Please download it from the official link and select Personal during installation. No registration is required — if you see a registration prompt, simply click the close button in the upper right corner. Then, provide me with the ID and verification code shown in the screenshot. I’ve just started work (it’s 10:50 AM now), so I can quickly resolve your issue.

ToDesk:
device ID:171 141 898
Temporary password:dr81qh48


On Tue, Aug 19, 2025 at 10:51 PM service@simsonn.com

Hi Shane Clore,     Several customers have reported the same issue, and we will need some time to provide a complete fix. For now, the fastest and most effective workaround is to use four M4×8 round-head nylon screws (non-metal material) together with M4×10×1.2 insulating washers (non-metal material). Similar-sized non-metal components will also work. The main purpose is to isolate the VAM Pro motor from the brake pedal, thereby completely eliminating interference with the brake sensor signal. Please note that this interference is not caused by vibration, but by direct contact.  Verifying this method is quite simple: remove the VAM Pro motor from the brake pedal so that it no longer makes contact, then test the vibration while monitoring the signal in VKB. You will notice that the throttle and clutch do not have this issue, since their pressure sensors are isolated by design.
Can you share what it should look like in VKB when testing the motors? Then I can compare to what it is doing now versus after fixing it with the non metal material hardware. Sent from my iPhone

Hi Shane Clore,  You only need to remove the brake motor and perform the test. When you click to activate the motor vibration, the interference disappears; however, once the motor touches the brake pedal again, the interference reappears. This phenomenon can be clearly observed in VKB, especially when the force is set to 0%.
I guess I don’t know what VKB should look like when I remove and test. Can you share a screenshot of what it should look like within VKB when testing properly looking motors? Sent from my iPhone

Hi Shane Clore,     When you press the brake signal to around 20%, the red line represents the brake input. Under normal conditions, the signal should remain stable, but when interference occurs, it shows a waveform fluctuation similar to the arrow.

Issue still persists after buying the nylon screw and washers… there is still interference whenever I test the signal.. 

If I remove the motors and put them on the carpet there is no issue when testing. I have still yet to use these as intended after spending $150 on these. 

Sent from my iPhone  

>

Hi Shane Clore,  The nylon washers must be installed between the motor and the bracket, otherwise the isolation will not be effective. You may also consider installing two washers at once to ensure effective isolation when securing the bracket.

I had nylon screws and washers installed. The washers were installed between the haptic motors and the bracket to the pedal..



Sent from my iPhone  

>

Hi Shane Clore,  Are you available now? I can assist you remotely to check the issue. In theory, using nylon screws has the same effect as when you placed the motor on the carpet earlier, since it eliminates conductive interference between metal parts.
Hi Shane Clore,     Is the blue VAM Pro touching the pedal’s motor bracket or the pedal arm at any point?

This is what it looks like. Nothing is touching the bracket.. Sorry, I’m in the US so timing is challenging to connect live.
